content:
ry 2, 2014
												Despite already owning a copy for the Xbox 360, I do not regret purchasing this game on Steam as well. As it would turn out, when DICE isn't busy in an uphill battle with Call of Duty, they have the ability to churn out works of art like this one.The storyline of this game is one that I met with a resounding 'eh'. Despite having a brilliant setup with many different directions to go in, it goes for the more subtle route based on what the main character, Faith finds most important. I wont spoil it too much, but I will say that your character, in this game at least isn't going to be playing the great big hero. But also not an antihero. Her job of transporting sensitive information as discreetly as possible is iffy at best, but at her core she clearly cares about others, even more than herself. I'd like to see Mirror's Edge 2 explore the more story driven aspect, but Mirrors' Edge's story is just alright.But everything else about this game feels like gold. Between the beautiful visuals which shine through even on lower end hardware, the amazing(if occasionally redundant) musical score, and the phoenominal gameplay, you not only get a stunning experience, but a deeply emotional one, too, and not in terms of a storyline. When I hop in an elevator and rapidly click the up button while bullet holes spur up in the door after being chased by 20 cops, I let out the same breath of fresh air Faith does. And when Faith takes a plunge to her death during a particularly adrenaline pumping chase sequence, I almost feel like I'm going to actually die.This whole package is wrapped up in a fantastically optimized piece of software. I own a low end machine, and the framerate ranges from dreamlike to slightly choppy, but it never becomes unplayable or difficult to control, even on an entry level laptop. And I can only imagine what it must be like to play on a higher end piece of hardware.The way the game works with a controller is, while unconventional, very smooth and well put together, but the keyboard and mouse is where it's at with this title. I'll spare the details, but all I can say is that you don't know good control until you've touched a DICE game.Another largely refreshing aspect is the gunplay. Traditional aim assisting mechanics have been foregone for a greater sense of realism. It not only feels refreshing to have gunplay be more skill based than about getting your crosshairs relatively near the target, but it also provides an incentive for you to drop your weapons periodically. With no reloads or tons of ammo, and most weapons weighing you down from sprinting or doing the parkour moves this game is great for, it provides the player a reason to not just lug around a big weapon all the time.The game's biggest drawback however is the production value. It certainly did get a solid budget being a AAA release, but some... interesting design decisions were made in lieu of a larger budget. The Flash animated cutscenes are some of the best Flash animations I've seen in a LONG time, but they feel somewhat out of place with the rest of the game's style. Not to mention the clunkiness behind grabbing your opponents' gun could really be worked on. Last but not least, the game was short for what it was. The campaign is only a few hours long, and with no multiplayer to pad it out(unless you like time trials) and a lack of mod support, you'll be left hungry for more. And even with how few levels there are, some of them are fairly boring, such as generic boat, generic high security building, and not to mention, generic subway station. However, all of these are refreshed a bit with the art style being so fantastic, but at the end of the day I would've liked to see more creative ventures like you in The Shard or New Eden Mall.No matter the production value, however, this game is well worth the $20 price, and an absolute must have if you ever see it on sale. You probably wont need to worry too much about if your computer can run it decently, so long as you have at least a 2.6 GhZ CPU(counting cores) and a half decent graphics card. Mirror's Edge is an experience that I think everyone should have.

y 21, 2014
												Mirror's Edge has done something not many games do. It combined visuals and gameplay into such a unique experience that you cannot find in much games. Mirror's Edge takes the term 'parkour' to such an extreme level. You're literally traveling from building to building. With your FEET. The only other game I can think of that takes free-running to such an extent would be Assassin's Creed, only first-person and modern. The visuals, thankfully made with the Frostbite engine, are spectacular. Especially if you have the right PC setup. The style is amazing, with the mostly white metropolis brightly lighting up objectives and significant building with color-schemes for every level. Not only are you running from enemies, but you have to fight them too. In most situations, you choose between fight or flight. Stealth is an option, but a hard one. After taking out an enemy, you can pick up their weapon and use it against your enemies. The thing is, there is no ammo count; you only use the ammo in the clip and discard the gun. This enthuses players to go the traditional parkour gameplay of the game. The game is not that long, since I beat it in a short 4-hour session. But it has decent replayability, being encouraged to try to beat your time throughout the levels. The story... is pretty dull. I won't talk about the story, but it's a bit cliche. For the price, I think this game is definitely worth buying, with its original gameplay and concepts that you can't really get anywhere else.

												Mirror's Edge is a fun, fast paced first person parkour game where you get to play as Faith, a runner(someone who act as a courier to transmit messages while evading government surveillance) as she escapes countless encounters with the government hunting her down. It's a game where you have to parkour over objects and obstacles to reach your point of destination, occasionally fighting enemies with melee and firearms. I personally feel like the game would have been better without the shooting parts. It kind of interferes with the pace of the game imo. The graphics are beautiful, they still look good. Overall, it's a great game for anyone who wants to experience a first person parkour game.Sound: 7.5/10 pretty goodGraphics: 8/10 good for their time, still looks good todayGameplay: 9/10 It's innovative and good for what it does.Characters: 5/10 nothing really interesting about themStory: 5/10 It has a good premise but it doesn't really get better than that, pretty lacking.Overall: 7/10 awesome game, get it if you like first person parkour

However, don't enable Nvidia's PhysX or whatever if you don't have an Nvidia card, or whenever glass breaks it will LAAAAAAAAAAAAG. Might have just been me though.Overall, I would highly reccomend this game.

												Mirror's Edge is a fun, fast paced first person parkour game where you get to play as Faith, a runner(someone who act as a courier to transmit messages while evading government surveillance) as she escapes countless encounters with the government hunting her down. 												Freedom.That's pretty much what this game made me feel. The platforming and running mechanics amazingly portrayed what parkour is all about. And the game gives off a definite feeling of speed and momentum as you navigate the few levels the base game has to offer. And that feeling is emphasized even further by the vibrant and colorful environments. The premise is neat but how they told the story and the characterization could have been done better. That's kinda disappointing since the player character, Faith, is pretty much a badass.Only thing though is don't buy it on Steam. Buy the game on Origin, EA's own client, because for some absurd reason the great Time Trials DLC is not for sale here on Steam. The DLC is worth it because it's just pure running and none of the atrocious combat is present.

												In this game, your objective is to run, climb, jump, etc to reach the end of the level. It's pretty much a parkour simulator with guns and combat sprinkled in here and there for a bit of variety.The combat system is alright, but I just wish it flowed better into and from the parkour because stopping to fight or disarm an enemy slows the game down a lot.The story isn't that good, but for your first playthrough I still reccommend watching the cutscenes just to understand whats going on in the game.The game is organised into chapters, all of which are fun and at no point in the game did I ever say "Oh no, here comes THAT part".This is one of the few first person games I've played where I actually feel like I'm controlling a real person, instead of a floating head who can shoot guns. This comes from the fact that movement is fluid and responsive, and if you look down you can actually see your character's body.The main character who you play as, Faith, is a woman, but doesn't come across as the "STONG, INDEPENDENT, DON'T NEED NO MAN" type. This is a good thing thing because I despise feminazis and SJWs.A lot of the problems with this game seem to be fixed with the sequel releasing next year, which I am eagerly awaiting because this is one of my favourite games I've ever played.Go buy it, it's dirt cheap.

												Really good game, pretty short but that just helps it to not get old.Mind blowing textures (not so much models, but hey, those textures are amazing) on walls, pipes, and pretty much everything.Really good fast-paced 3D platforming with a good use of enviromental movement.The biggest flaw of the game is how it suddenly focuses in combat near the end of the game and the combat isn't particularly great, even worse, this combat sections aren't even optional, you are forced to fight many soldiers while the whole main focus of the game was running away.There's a story but it isn't anything spectacular or mind blowing, not even surprising at all in my opinion, it's just there for the sake of making the aesthetics of the game stand out even more, which is ok but there's more that could've done to it.Overall a good and pretty unique experience, if they ever make a sequel to this game lets hope they ditch the combat entirely and it'll be even better.
